articles.headline: In San Francisco and Rooting for a Tech Comeuppance
articles.snippet: The city is bulging, the rents soaring, and residents are growing more vocal about wishing Silicon Valley would cool off, or at least pay up.
articles.abstract: The city is bulging, the rents soaring, and residents are growing more vocal about wishing Silicon Valley would cool off, or at least pay up.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — These are anxious days in the land of start-ups. Another few months of tight money and the entrepreneurs and venture capitalists will be feeling real pain.

articles.headline: E.U. Woos Turkey for Refugee Help, Ignoring Rights Crackdown
articles.snippet: To win help with the migrant crisis, Europe seems prepared to overlook what critics say is President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s march toward authoritarianism.
articles.abstract: To win help with the migrant crisis, Europe seems prepared to overlook what critics say is President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s march toward authoritarianism.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The contrast was jarring: Just days after the police broke into the offices of an opposition newspaper using tear gas and water cannons, Turkey’s prime minister was greeted in Brussels with offers of billions in aid, visa-free travel for Turks in Europe and renewed prospects for joining the European Union.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Reviving the Working Class Without Building Walls
articles.snippet: On the wrong side of globalization, workers supporting Donald Trump have embraced his proposals. But there are better ways to make things better.
articles.abstract: On the wrong side of globalization, workers supporting Donald Trump have embraced his proposals. But there are better ways to make things better.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can the government help Donald Trump’s supporters?

articles.headline: A Future Without Jobs? Two Views of the Changing Work Force
articles.snippet: The Business Day columnists Eduardo Porter and Farhad Manjoo discuss the concept of a universal basic income and the trajectory of our economy.
articles.abstract: The Business Day columnists Eduardo Porter and Farhad Manjoo discuss the concept of a universal basic income and the trajectory of our economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the utopian (dystopian?) future projected by technological visionaries, few people would have to work. Wealth would be generated by millions upon millions of sophisticated machines. But how would people earn a living?
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Farhad Manjoo

articles.headline: Maria Sharapova’s Admission Sends Her Sponsors Fleeing
articles.snippet: In suspending their ties with the tennis star, Nike and other companies acted faster than other sponsors had in similar circumstances.
articles.abstract: In suspending their ties with the tennis star, Nike and other companies acted faster than other sponsors had in similar circumstances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maria Sharapova’s announcement on Monday that she had failed a drug test at the Australian Open was shocking. But perhaps more surprising was how quickly some of her sponsors turned their backs on her.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Wins Michigan Primary; Donald Trump Takes 3 States
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders’s upset in Michigan threatened to prolong the Democratic campaign. Mr. Trump’s victories demonstrated his popularity in the Midwest and South.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders’s upset in Michigan threatened to prolong the Democratic campaign. Mr. Trump’s victories demonstrated his popularity in the Midwest and South.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump easily dispatched his Republican rivals in the Michigan and Mississippi presidential primaries Tuesday and won the Hawaii caucuses, regaining momentum in the face of intensifying resistance to his campaign among party leaders.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: F.D.A. Deal Allows Amarin to Promote Drug for Off-Label Use
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration will now allow Amarin to sell Vascepa, an omega-3 fatty acid, for both high and low triglyceride levels.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration will now allow Amarin to sell Vascepa, an omega-3 fatty acid, for both high and low triglyceride levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a deal that could change the way some companies market their drugs, the Food and Drug Administration has agreed to allow a pharmaceutical company to promote a drug for a use that the agency has not approved, the company said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Obama Seeks to Pave Way to Mideast Deal After He Leaves Office
articles.snippet: President Obama is looking past his time in office and weighing a plan that would preserve at least the principle of a two-state solution for his successor to pursue.
articles.abstract: President Obama is looking past his time in office and weighing a plan that would preserve at least the principle of a two-state solution for his successor to pursue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, resigned to his failure to broker a peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians, is looking past his time in office and weighing a plan that would preserve at least the principle of a two-state solution for his successor to pursue.

articles.headline: Trade and Jobs Key to Victory for Bernie Sanders
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders won the primary by appealing to white working-class voters, while Hillary Clinton had emphasized the auto industry bailout and the contaminated water in Flint.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders won the primary by appealing to white working-class voters, while Hillary Clinton had emphasized the auto industry bailout and the contaminated water in Flint.
articles.lead_paragraph: No Democratic presidential candidate had campaigned in Traverse City, Mich., in decades until Senator Bernie Sanders pulled up to the concert hall near the Sears store on Friday. Some 2,000 people mobbed him when he arrived, roaring in approval as he called the country’s trade policies, and Hillary Clinton’s support for them, “disastrous.”
articles.byline: By Yamiche Alcindor and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: After Living Brazil’s Dream, Family Confronts Microcephaly and Economic Crisis
articles.snippet: In the wake of the Zika epidemic, hundreds of families in northeastern Brazil are facing the prospect of raising a disabled child in poverty.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the Zika epidemic, hundreds of families in northeastern Brazil are facing the prospect of raising a disabled child in poverty.
articles.lead_paragraph: IPOJUCA, Brazil — They were young and relishing Brazil’s version of the American dream: buying a car, joining a church, starting a family.

articles.headline: Florida, Famed for Political Spectacles, Braces for Another as Primary Nears
articles.snippet: The dizzying race descends on the delegate-rich state over the next week, as one of its senators, Marco Rubio, looks to make a stand against Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: The dizzying race descends on the delegate-rich state over the next week, as one of its senators, Marco Rubio, looks to make a stand against Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Get live updates about the Florida primary.

articles.headline: The Echo From Amazon Brims With Groundbreaking Promise
articles.snippet: The voice-controlled computer has the potential to become a dominant force in the most intimate of environments: our homes.
articles.abstract: The voice-controlled computer has the potential to become a dominant force in the most intimate of environments: our homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many of the world’s largest technology companies have spent the last five years searching in vain for the holy grail, a machine to succeed the smartphone as the next must-have gadget.

articles.headline: Master of Go Board Game Is Walloped by Google Computer Program
articles.snippet: The match between Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo and Lee Se-dol was seen as a test of how far research into artificial intelligence has come.
articles.abstract: The match between Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo and Lee Se-dol was seen as a test of how far research into artificial intelligence has come.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Computer, one. Human, zero.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and John Markoff
